subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Book suggestions for translation.
msgSnippet: Yes, translate something short such as sherlock holmes, etc.  Or, some non-religious inspiring thoughts from great people.  That should be interesting.  You
messageBody:
Yes, translate something short such as sherlock holmes, etc.  Or, some non-religious inspiring thoughts from great people.  That should be interesting.  You don't have to translate something that will take years to finish.  BTW, I read and write my own Quikskript but have no idea what people are talking about when they talk about unicode, etc.  Maybe you could just translate what all this means because I have almost given up on trying to understand what this technical talk is all about.  I think it discourages beginners from taking up quikscript frankly.i

--- On Fri, 7/29/11, peter_r_guinness <bacedif@...> wrote:

From: peter_r_guinness <bacedif@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Book suggestions for translation.
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, July 29, 2011, 6:15 PM

 

I'm thinking about translating another book to QS for use as beginner's practise reading material.

Please note: that the book must be without copywrite- so all the Gutenberg Project books are good candidates. Also the book should be short and with simple English- so a popular children's book less than 150 pages would be ideal (eg: Alice in Wonderland).

Anyone have any suggestions/personal favourites they would like to read in QS?

PS: I would really like to do the Hobbit- but unfortunately it is not yet out of copyright.
